content.description:
This is a wild pitch that traverses through the whole roof, and around the corner to connect with the upper crux of Space Invaders.  Perfect stone and great exposure!



This pitch begins at the belay above the first pitches of Zelda and Qbert.  Clip the first two bolts of Qbert to begin, and then follow the bolt line out right across the roof to where the climb intersects with Space Invaders, follow the crux of that pitch to the top anchors.

This route works best if the leader then lowers to the cave ledge belay of Space Invaders to belay the second from there.  Or, just belay from the top. 

13 bolts

A 5.8 pitch at Lillooet Edge!  This is a long pitch of fantastic 5.8 climbing to a gorgeous high ledge.

Avoid the dirty crack to the left for great face climbing on the bolt line, at the little roof move up through the crack onto the first ledge, 5.8.  There is an anchor here for top-roping the first tier section, if you're  continuing the pitch, just skip this anchor and clip the next bolt, in fact, don't even touch the ledge!  The second tier is amazing easy face climbing.  The 5.8 crux is at the very top.  Make a move and reach for jugs at the lip to pull into the cave ledge.



Just around the corner from the Zelda platform.  The farthest bolt line to the left.  Start at the crack in the detached block.

9 bolts, chains

Up the slab crack to the ledge, steep crimps up the beautiful wall, then work the arete.  Stop at the anchor there for top-roping, or continue up the arete past one more bolt to the big ledge and the second pitch.

P2 - To the right of the anchor, make a boulder move to start, climb over edges, then make a magical traverse left, up through some more ledges, to a nice clean, hard slab finish.



At the bottom of the Arcade, start up the slab crack corner, past two bolts.

bolts all the way

This is a short, steep, hard variation.  Head out right from the Poisoner's Apprentice and crank up through the overlaps.  Then move back left to rejoin Poisoner's.


bolts

This is a significant variation on a route climbed by the original developers of the area, Robin and Nick Barley, in 1992.  The first pitch-and-a-half are new, and it is fully bolted to the top, including the awesome layback flake of the original route called "Lichen Salad"  There was indeed a lot of lichen and moss to clean off at Lillooet Edge.

Scenic, varied but sustained 5.10- climbing to the top of the cliff, this route also lends itself well to being climbed in a single 50m pitch.

P1 - Start from the stacked rocks, traverse left after the first bolt (ignore the old 1/4" bolt up higher) then make a big move after the second bolt, continue up to the big ledge, 5.10a.  Clip a long draw here and continue up the second tier.  Nearing the top of the pitch there is a choice to be made.  Clip the righthand bolt and pull over a right-leaning undercling arch 5.10c, or, clip the lefthand bolt and traverse leftward to use slanting cracks before trending back into the plumb line 5.10a.

Belay at the anchor bolts on the slanting ledge.

P2 - From the ledge, follow the lefthand bolt line up over steep blocks to a small slab section midway, shake it out there and then move right into the pumpy and sustained layback crack  to the top.  5.10b

Enjoy the view!



Start at the wooden platform further to the right of Thunderclap Wall.  Follow the bolt line on the left, up the wide groove.

There is also a set of anchor bolts on the first big ledge (15m up) they can be used to toprope the bottom section, or just clipped for pro as you continue up the first pitch.

about 10 bolts per pitch

Best to head up the Dig Dug start, clip those first few bolts, up to the little roof, then follow the line of bolts to the right, up through the groove, then a delicate move right and up the slabs to finish.


bolts, to chains

climbs.name: Qbert
climbs.fa: Jay Audenart, mar 2020, bolted by JD Hare

content.description:
This climb pulls directly through the impressive roof to the right of Zelda.

P1 - Climb the bolt line on the right, directly towards the big fir tree on the ledge.  This is a great 15m of climbing.  There is only one problem.  The final move is manteling onto the ledge on slopers, and the dirt the big tree is living in is constantly shedding onto the lip, so, be prepared for a sandy sloper mantle onto the first big ledge.  Use the tree!  5.10d

From the first ledge, climb the Zelda bolt line to the belay.  Take the right bolt variation near the top, pulling through the undercling arch 5.10c   

P2 - Move right from the belay, then follow the bolt line straight up through the roof.  This is pumpy, but the crux is actually above this, on slabbier terrain, making a delicate traverse move to the right before finishing to the anchor on a cute little ledge.  5.11b

This is not really the end of the route.  This little ledge is still about 8m below the top of the cliff.  There is a beautiful open-book micro crack to be climbed from there. (5.12+?)



Start at the wooden platform further to the right of Thunderclap Wall.  Follow the bolt line on the right, up the steep wall.

There is also a set of anchor bolts on the first big ledge (15m up) they can be used to toprope the bottom section, or just clipped for pro as you continue up the first pitch.

10 bolts, then 6

The second pitch of Space Invaders, though shorter, is one of the best at LE, 5.10b.  And it can be reached more easily via Dig Dug.  In fact, these pitches string together beautifully to create a gradually intensifying, 60m long, 5.10b sport pitch.

The first pitch is also one of the finer pitches at LE, and makes a great single pitch sport climb, 5.10c.  To join them you just have to clip one more bolt beyond the first set of chains and climb a few more metres and mantels to the cave belay.

P1 - Follow the first four bolts of Dig Dug ad then pull directly over the little roof, head up the pillar, veering to the left up to a good jug, then traverse a move back to the right and make balancy moves on good feet up to the final mantel onto the ledge. 5.10c

Set up a sport anchor here, or continue on past another bolt to get to the cave ledge.  If you're climbing the next pitch, and worried about the belayer getting yanked up into the roof, clip the fixed nut as well for a directional.

P2 - Clip the bolt overhead and step left out of the cave.  The first crux is here, getting to the second bolt.  Cruise up through the beautiful black rock of the middle section to a full rest on a high ledge.  Move up to the jug in the groove, and then commit leftward onto the bulging arete and crank directly up it on good holds.  



Start as for Dig Dug, up the crack in the detached block.

about 10 bolts per pitch

climbs.name: The Unknown Poisoner
climbs.fa: Guy Edwards, Robin Barley, 1993 - renovated and second pitch prepared in 2022 by JD Hare

content.description:
This is obviously a great trad route.  The problem was scrambling up to the ledge.  Now that it's cleaned and bolted for Double Dragon, it's actually a really cool start to this burly 5.9+ corner crack.  The other problem with this route is there is some kind of poison ivy up there.  I have tried to kill it but it just won't die.  If you see a bush growing at about 2/3 up the crack, just don't touch it.  You don't have to.  You can climb past it no problem.  Don't let it deter you, this is a really awesome pitch.  There is a top anchor there now for this, and for DD.  You can climb to there and session it, or you can continue up the wider crack to the big ledge.  

P2 - You can continue up another crack system, up a chimney with a lot of loose blocks in it, and up into a lower-angle thin finger crack to the top.  There's another anchor at the top of that.



Start as for Double Dragon, at the bottom of the zone, up the slab crack, past two bolts up to the big ledge.


full standard rack, anchors everywhere you need them.

This is where the majority of the new-route development has been done.  These routes are a little cleaner and friendlier :) 
 As with the Original zone of LE, the real pay-off is in the upper pitches.
